Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2018 10:09AM teachermomfl wrote: Ugh...the waiting is the worst! I had a stereotactic biopsy (mammo guided) last month. It was uncomfortable, as the girls were squished in a mammo machine while I laid face down, but the biopsy itself didn't hurt. The numbed the area, and I didn't really feel anything. Make sure you have a tight sports bra to wear after.I didn't feel any pain until later that night and a little the next day. That stinks that you were all ready to have it done, only to have to reschedule. I hope everything goes well!

I've also been reading the excisional biopsy seems to be standard protocol when abnormal cells are found.
Posts.Title: Microcalcifications behind nipple teachermomfl teachermomfl

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2017 11:59AM teachermomfl wrote: I think the same way you do. The unknown is awful. I'm a bit of a control freak (probably more than a bit), and I hate not knowing & the feeling of having no control. I'm sorry about your wait situation. Is your hematoma from the stereo biopsy? Thankfully, mine has healed up nicely. I hate starting the new year with a surgery, as our deductible resets. I'm thankful to have medical insurance, but I truly hate the insurance companies. I feel like in these situations, the insurance company should do what it can do to expedite things. We'll probably have to pay out of pocket Tuesday. Our HSA card expires the end of December. We called the company and inquired as to why we haven't received a replacement, and they mailed out new cards. I took my daughter to a doctor appointment yesterday and discovered that the HSA company cancelled our current card when the mailed out the new one. WTH?! We'll be able to submit invoices for reimbursement, but jeez...I'll be keeping track of you as well. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Heading to my excisional biopsy momto3sons beach2beach

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2018 03:06PM teachermomfl wrote: I have two adult children and one 16 year old. I had calcifications show on my annual mammo in Nov. Went back for diagnostic in December. Was referred for stereo biopsy in late December. MRI in January and excisional biopsy in early February. The only thing that showed was ADH. As you can see, this went on for quite a long period of time. I didn't tell them anything. That would be a long time for them to worry about something that was not cancerous. I agree with DJ Mammo, unless you need their help to drive to/from appointments, I would wait.

Posts.Title: Pending Excisional Breast Biopsy StrongJess momto3sons

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2017 11:21AM teachermomfl wrote: Officially joining the club. A little about me: 42 years old, with a history of cysts and very dense breasts. Started getting mammos about 4 years ago. Always get called back for diagnostic and ultrasound due to breast density. Have had a few cysts aspirated when they've gotten to be too big. Went for annual in November. Was called back (as usual), but this time for calcifications. After magnification mammo,the radiologist took me in a room to talk (that's never happened). They were concerned, as the microcalcifications were in clusters and in a linear pattern. Stereotactic biopsy last week. Results yesterday of ADH. Doctor from hospital said they are very concerned about what may be behind the area they biopsied. I have an appointment with breast surgeon next week. Hospital doc said to plan on surgery to remove more tissue for testing. I know this is going to sound weird, but my biggest concern is taking time off work. I'm a teacher, and I hate missing. Every day missed is one day lost of instructional time for my kiddos. Anyways, just wanted to introduce myself, as I've been lurking on this thread since yesterday. -Paula
Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: May 9, 2018 04:52PM teachermomfl wrote: ADH friends, I have a question & I think this is the best place to post it. As some of you know, I was diagnosed with ADH in my left breast in December after a stereotactic biopsy, and it was removed during an excisional biopsy. Started Tamoxifen in March, and next mammo and appointment with breast surgeon is in August. This morning in the shower, I felt a new palpable lump in my right breast. It's at about the 12 o'clock spot, a few inches above the nipple. I have very fibrocystic breasts, so I assume it's a cyst. Do you recommend calling my breast surgeon since it's new and palpable? I hate the thought of more appointments for something that may just be a cyst. What do y'all think?
Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2018 01:53PM teachermomfl wrote: I've never heard of ultrasound being recommended before mammo. Did the radiologist confirm it's a cyst? Absolutely talk to your midwife about this, but if you have dense breasts, the mammo will likely not show anything the ultrasound didn't.You can try for an MRI, but they can be hard to get approved by insurance unless you've been diagnosed with something already, like cancer or ADH. If it is a cyst, it may be difficult to aspirate, given the location. I'm sorry you were treated this way by the imaging center.
Posts.Title: I was refused a mammogram. What now? JenniferEver bevin

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2018 06:30PM teachermomfl wrote: Thanks for posting, Jess! I’m glad everything went well. Less than a week for mine. I go in Thursday to have my Savi Scout piece put in. My hospital uses this rather than the wires. It’s a similar procedure to stereo biopsy, only rather than suck something out, they insert the Savi Scout antenna. It’s about the size of a grain of rice. My biopsy is Friday, and my surgeon will use some handheld device to locate the antenna so he know she where to cut. Pretty high tech, and I’m surprised my insurance would cover it, as it was just approved by the FDA a few months ago. Hoping for benign results for you
Posts.Title: Pending Excisional Breast Biopsy StrongJess momto3sons

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2018 10:24PM teachermomfl wrote: I've not had an aspiration while nursing, however I've had numerous aspirations for cysts. It is a very simple procedure. The doctor will numb your skin, use an ultrasound to find the cyst, insert a needle and withdraw the fluid. Very simple and quick. Good luck!

Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2018 03:12PM teachermomfl wrote: If it was your first ultrasound, they generally take longer as they are establishing a baseline of sorts. My first one too forever, because I have very cystic breasts. She had to measure and log the size of each cyst. In my personal experience, the one time I had something truly concerning show, they asked me to wait so the radiologist could speak with me. I hope that alleviates some of your jitters.
Posts.Title: Waiting game. Lxs MayDayMelK

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2019 04:11PM teachermomfl wrote: I have a history of cysts, and they can grow quickly. The ultrasound can tell if it's a cyst or solid. If it's cyst, and it's bothering you, they can just drain it. They typically don't send anything for biopsy, as it's just fluid and cysts are benign. I've had many drained, it's very easy and painless.

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2018 03:28PM teachermomfl wrote: Not at all. I had a stereotactic biopsy in December after an abnormal mammo & ultrasound. It was ADH, so I had to have an excisional biopsy. I had my MRI a few weeks before the biopsy to get a baseline. There ended up being no cancer, just ADH.
